training_organizations.name: Virginia DSS – Child Welfare Professional Development (VCU Partnership)
training_organizations.description: Virginia’s Department of Social Services partners with Virginia Commonwealth University to coordinate training for the child welfare workforce. Through the VCU Child Welfare Training Program, new Family Services Specialists (who work for local county/city DSS offices) are trained in Virginia’s policies, the Structured Decision Making tools Virginia uses, and skills like engaging families and documentation. Ongoing professional development opportunities are also provided to local DSS staff to maintain and enhance their competencies.

training_organizations.name: United Methodist Family Services (UMFS)
training_organizations.description: A nonprofit child-placing agency in Virginia that provides a range of services under contract with local DSS agencies. UMFS runs therapeutic foster care programs – recruiting and training foster families for children with significant emotional/behavioral needs – and also operates residential treatment and private special education schools. Approximately half of Virginia’s foster children are placed through private agencies like UMFS:contentReference[oaicite:49]{index=49}, which manage those foster homes and provide supportive services while local DSS retain legal case oversight.

training_organizations.name: Intercept Health
training_organizations.description: A private agency in Virginia (formerly known as Intercept Youth Services) that offers foster care, mental health, and youth support programs. Intercept recruits foster families and manages placements especially for older youth and those with behavioral challenges. They also provide in-home counseling and life skills coaching. Many local Virginia DSS agencies partner with Intercept to place children who need a higher level of care or to provide wraparound services to families in reunification, illustrating Virginia’s heavy use of contracted providers to deliver front-line foster care and services:contentReference[oaicite:50]{index=50}.

training_organizations.name: West Virginia DHHR – Child Welfare Training
training_organizations.description: The West Virginia Department of Health & Human Resources provides training for child protective services workers and youth services workers through its Office of Training. With a centralized state system, WV ensures all new CPS employees complete a training academy focusing on state law (Chapter 49 of WV Code), investigation protocols, and the state’s family-centered practice model. Ongoing training addresses areas like substance abuse in families, legal updates, and engaging kinship caregivers.

training_organizations.name: NECCO (West Virginia)
training_organizations.description: A private foster care agency that operates in West Virginia under contracts to provide therapeutic foster care and related services. NECCO recruits foster families across WV, trains them (including on handling special needs or behaviors), and then facilitates placements for children referred by DHHR. NECCO case managers monitor the child and support the foster family. By contracting with NECCO, West Virginia can serve children who might not thrive in regular foster homes, and the state benefits from NECCO’s expertise in behavioral health and intensive home-based services.

training_organizations.name: Mission West Virginia
training_organizations.description: A nonprofit that runs the Frameworks program, which helps DHHR with foster/adoptive parent recruitment and retention. Mission WV conducts public awareness campaigns, informational meetings, and PRIDE trainings for prospective foster/adoptive families. It also offers support groups and resources to families after licensure. This NGO partnership bolsters West Virginia’s efforts to find more qualified foster and kinship homes so that children in care can be placed with families rather than in congregate care whenever possible.

policies.TribalFoster: No, Tribes within state do not provide foster care
policies.InvestQual_SW: Yes, recommended or preferred, but not required
policies.DecentralScreen: Each county/region has own screening unit
policies.ScreenerQual_SW: Yes, recommended or preferred, but not required
policies.FatalitiesReview: Yes, reviews are required for all or some cases
policies.Def_Subtype_Abuse: Physical abuse includes Munchausen syndrome by proxy, bizarre discipline, abusive head trauma and battered child syndrome, exposure to sale or manufacturing of certain controlled substances; Sexual abuse includes sexual exploitation, intercourse and sodomy, and trafficking; Mental abuse may include bizarre discipline, and exposure to domestic violence
policies.CaseManagerQual_SW: Yes, recommended or preferred, but not required
policies.Def_Subtype_Neglect: Physical neglect includes abandonment, inadequate supervision, inadequate clothing, inadequate shelter, inadequate personal hygiene, inadequate food, leaving the child with a person registered as a violent sex offender, nonorganic failure to thrive, labor trafficking; Mental neglect may include bizarre discipline, domestic violence, or nonorganic failure to thrive
policies.Exempt_OtherSpecify: Organic failure to thrive (as opposed to non-organic failure to thrive which is considered maltreatment)
policies.Reporter_OtherSpecify: Animal control officers; Mediators certified to receive court referrals; People employed by institutions of higher education; Persons 18 years or older associated with or employed by any public or private organization responsible for the care, custody, and control of children; Any person 18 years of age or older, who has received training approved by the Department of Social Services for the purposes of recognizing and reporting child abuse and neglect; Any person employed by a local department of social services (LDSS) who determines eligibility for public assistance; Any person who engages in the practice of behavioral analysis
policies.InvestReq_OtherSpecify: Assessment summary of strengths and needs; Inquire if subject of the report has resided outside of Virginia within the last 5 years; Identifying individuals in the kinship network providing support and resources to family and child
policies.ScreenReq_OtherSpecify: Screening for domestic violence; Human trafficking assessments
policies.ReportInfo_OtherSpecify: Availability of a family member who can protect the child; Special language needs of the family; Information about child or adult developmental issues; Information about any disabilities or diagnoses of the child; Information about ongoing or prior substance abuse
policies.ScreenInfo_OtherSpecify: Jurisdiction in which the child resides or where maltreatment occurred
policies.InHome_PostReunification: Yes--implemented in specific counties or regions
policies.InvestStaff_OtherSpecify: Investigations of out of family complaints (including facilities and foster homes) are conducted jointly between the assigned Family Services Specialist and the appointed regulatory staff person of the public agency with authority (or designee if the facility is not a state regulatory authority, such as in schools)
policies.DefPerp_VaryByTypeSpecify: For sex trafficking or severe forms of trafficking, the alleged abuser may be any person regardless of whether they have been identified; For sexual abuse or sexual exploitation, the alleged abuser may be the alleged victim child's parent, other caretaker, or an intimate partner of such parent or caretaker.
policies.InvestQual_TrainingSpecify: Uniform trainings on core competencies and critical training in guidance and law specific to current practice issues and 24 contact hours annually of continuing education/training required for investigators and supervisors; Supervisors must complete the Family Services CORE Supervisor Training Series within first two years of employment; Additional specialized training is required for investigators and supervisors who conduct out of family and sexual abuse investigations
policies.ScreenProcess_OtherSpecify: The local department of social services (LDSS) with jurisdiction must use the Child Protective Services Intake Tool
policies.CentralizedReporting_Specify: Local Departments of Social Services (LDSS) are responsible for receiving reports via telephone 24 hours/7 days a week. However, the Virginia Department of Social Services also has a 24 hour/7days a week state-wide toll-free child protective services hotline. Reports made to the state-wide hotline are immediately referred to the LDSS.
policies.InvestQual_ExperienceSpecify: 2 years of appropriate experience in a human services related area for individuals who do not possess a bachelor's degree in the human services field
policies.ReporterPenalty_OtherSpecify: Animal control officers; Mediators certified to receive court referrals; People employed by institutions of higher education; Persons 18 years or older associated with or employed by any public or private organization responsible for the care, custody, and control of children; Any person 18 years of age or older, who has received training approved by the Department of Social Services for the purposes of recognizing and reporting child abuse and neglect; Any person employed by a local department of social services (LDSS) who determines eligibility for public assistance; Any person who engages in the practice of behavioral analysis
policies.ScreenReq_OtherCases_Specify: Domestic violence screenings are required for all cases; Human trafficking assessments are required for all cases alleging a child is a victim of human trafficking unless during the course of the human trafficking assessment it is determined an investigation or family assessment is required by law or is necessary to protect the safety of the child.
policies.ScreenerQual_TrainingSpecify: Uniform trainings on core competencies and critical training in guidance and law specific to current practice issues and 24 contact hours annually of continuing education/training required for screeners and supervisors; Supervisors must also complete the Family Services CORE Supervisor Training Series within first two years of employment.
policies.InvestReq_MHEvalCases_Specify: Mental abuse or neglect or at the discretion of the investigative worker
policies.ScreenRiskAssess_OtherSpecify: Domestic violence screening tools such as the Hurt, Insult, Threaten, Scream (HITS) tool and Women's Experience with Battering (WEB) tool
policies.CaseManagerQual_ExperienceSpec: 2 years of appropriate experience in a human services related area for individuals who do not possess a bachelor's degree in the human services field
policies.InvestReq_MedEvalCases_Specify: Investigation of medical neglect of disabled infants with life-threatening conditions; If the local department of social services (LDSS) requests an examination
policies.ScreenerQual_ExperienceSpecify: 2 years of appropriate experience in a human services related area for individuals who do not possess a bachelor's degree in the human services field
policies.AltResp_EligibilityMaltreatment: Only certain types of maltreatment are eligible
policies.AltResp_EligibilityRiskToolSpec: Child Protective Services intake tool with decision tree to determine response priority; Safety assessment tool
policies.CaseManagerQual_TrainingSpecify: Uniform trainings on core competencies and critical training in guidance and law specific to current practice issues and 24 contact hours annually of continuing education/training are required for case managers and supervisors; Supervisors must complete the Family Services CORE Supervisor Training Series within first two years of employment
policies.ExtFosterCare_Reentry_OtherSpec: Youth must participate in a re-entry team meeting

policies.TribalFoster: No, there are no Tribes within the state
policies.TribalReport: No, there are no Tribes within the state
policies.TribalScreen: No, there are no Tribes within the state
policies.Def_OtherSpecify: Child conceived as a result of sexual assault
policies.FatalitiesReview: Yes, reviews are required for all or some cases
policies.Def_Subtype_Abuse: Abuse includes excessive corporal punishment, mental or emotional maltreatment, physical abuse, near fatality, sexual exploitation, sexual abuse, sale or attempted sale of a child, child exposed to domestic violence, child conceived as a result of sexual assault, human trafficking and attempted human trafficking
policies.Def_Subtype_Neglect: Neglect includes abandonment and failure/inability to supply necessary food, clothing, supervision, medical care (including hygiene), education, or necessary shelter
policies.NearFatalitiesReview: Yes, reviews are required for all or some cases
policies.InvestReq_OtherSpecify: The Child Protective Services (CPS) worker must: Collect information on child functioning, general parenting, parenting discipline, and adult functioning; Contact law enforcement, the prosecuting attorney or the medical examiner if the report involves serious physical injury, sexual abuse, sexual assault, death of a child, and cases of human trafficking to coordinate any arrangements for a joint investigation/family assessment.
policies.ReportInfo_OtherSpecify: Child's and caregiver's general condition; Account of present/impending dangers; Reporter's opinions about needed actions and child's safety; Identification of protective adults who are or may be available
policies.ScreenInfo_OtherSpecify: Identifying and other information of reporter; Identifying information of child's parents, guardian, or caregiver/caretaker; Identifying and other information of family/household members; Child's and caregiver's general condition; Account of present/impending dangers; How the child functions/behaves; Reporter's opinions about needed actions and child's safety; Information on prior maltreatment; Identification of protective adults who are or may be available
policies.AntiDiscrim_OtherSpecify: Limited proficiency in speaking, reading, writing or understanding the English language
policies.DefAge_VaryByTypeSpecify: Drug affected infant applies to children under 1
policies.DefPerp_VaryByTypeSpecify: For human trafficking, the perpetrator is a third party perpetrator
policies.InvestReq_MedEvalCases_Specify: Child fatalities; Sexual abuse; Cases involving serious physical injury
policies.ScreenerQual_ExperienceSpecify: 3 years of full-time or equivalent part-time social work experience in a public or private human services agency
policies.FalseReportPenalty_OtherSpecify: Regarding reports of child maltreatment against those with open or upcoming family court cases, if the Court determines, based on investigation or other evidence, that an accusation of child abuse or neglect, or domestic violence made during a child custody proceeding is false and the parent making the accusation knew it to be false at the time the accusation was made, the Court may order reimbursement to be paid by the person making the accusations of costs resulting from defending against the accusations
policies.InvestReq_PerpCrimCases_Specify: Cases involving allegations of child sex offender in the home; Prior domestic violence allegations
